title: Ticket #2453: Figure out why we can only run about 8 jobs on a windows exec node
description:
Figure out where the slowdown is that prevents us from running more than about 8 jobs simultaneously on a windows execute node with 40 slots/cores.

The problem is even worse without a PROCD.
remarks:
2011-Oct-03 10:24:57 by ichesal:
Pushed an update regarding the multple startd testing on the 40-core box to case #2441.

2011-Oct-13 16:30:10 by johnkn:
The fundamental problem here is that it can take so long for a STARTER to start up and phone home, that the SHADOW gives up and the result is that after about 10 jobs are running, slots can be claimed, but the claims cannot be activated.

The timeout for claim activation is only 20 seconds, but it takes longer and longer to create a STARTER process the more jobs that are running. I see a max of around 14 sec to create a STARTER in my testing with 40 slots on a 4 core machine.

Here's a representative log fragment

2011-Oct-13 16:58:50 by johnkn:
I created some specialized statistics probes and other runtime measurement code and determined that the problem is not the cost of creating a process per-se, but instead with the cost of Register_Family

With 40 slots and 40 jobs queued, I hever see more than about 12-14 jobs running simultaneously. (testing on 4 Core machine with 16Gb of ram running Win7 x64).

Here's the runtime values for Create_Process and Register_Family 

Who     Symbol                   Count  Average      Min      Max      Std
schedd DCCreate_Process000          50    0.008    0.002    0.041    0.006
schedd DCCreateProcessW32           50    0.010    0.000    0.163    0.034
schedd DCCreate_Process001          50    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000
schedd DCCreate_ProcessTot          50    0.018    0.005    0.168    0.034

startd DCCreate_Process000          24    0.172    0.002    4.049    0.826
startd DCCreateProcessW32           24    0.009    0.000    0.059    0.018
startd DCCreate_Process001          24    0.000    0.000    0.000    0.000
startd DCRregister_subfamily        23    9.272    3.672   22.183    4.977
startd DCRegister_Family            23    9.272    3.672   22.183    4.977
startd DCCreate_ProcessTot          24    9.316    0.003   22.192    5.113

Create_ProcessTot is the overall time spent in DaemonCore::Create_Process Create_Process000 is the DaemonCore::Create_Process before the actual CreateProcessAsUser call Create_ProcessW32 is the CreateProcessAsUser call Craete_Process001 is the remainder of DaemonCore::Create_Process not including Register_Family Register_Family is DaemonCore::Register_Family Register_subfamily is ProcFamilyDirect::register_subfamily

Because there is a PROCD the implementation of register_subfamily is to send a message via named-pipe to the procd and then wait for the result. The PROCD doesn't have a classad, so I used a different technique to get timing data for the calls. 

    Function        PerCall(ms)     Calls   Total(ms)
------------------- ----------- --------- -----------
 register_subfamily    7010.424        80  560833.990
 read_from_client         0.003        80       0.300
 write_to_client          0.112        80       8.972
        snapshot       6789.572       175 1188175.124
 getProcInfoList       6789.431       175 1188150.518
 iterProcInfoList         0.123       175      21.594
   remove_exited          0.008       175       1.437
  track_new_pids          0.003       175       0.543
 build_else_list          0.001       175       0.202
 delete_unwatched         0.000       175       0.171
    update_sizes          0.001       175       0.243
   procapi_calls          0.000       177       0.000
 procapi_queries          2.274       237     538.982
  procapi_allocs        286.720         1     286.720
 procapi_realocs          0.750        60      45.008
 bldProcInfoList       6789.430       175 1188150.270
 getProcPerfData          2.600       175     455.170
 getParentPID            33.526     35411 1187220.323

so buildProcInfoList is taking almost 7 seconds, and is calling getParentPID an average of 200 times with an average cost of 33ms per call.

2011-Oct-14 13:58:52 by tstclair:
If the change is conservative why not target 7.6 as this arose from the 7.6 series which is in the field.
